title: Erdős #671: Lagrange Interpolation Convergence
description: Can Lagrange interpolation L^n f(x) → f(x) even when the Lebesgue function λ_n(x) → ∞? Known: λ_n diverges somewhere (Bernstein), |L^n f| diverges a.e. for some f (Erdős-Vértesi). Prize: $250.

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Sergei Bernstein, Péter Vértesi

overview.historicalContext: Bernstein (1931) proved the Lebesgue function diverges at some point for any interpolation scheme. Erdős and Vértesi (1980) showed that for any points, some continuous function has |L^n f(x)| → ∞ almost everywhere. The questions ask whether convergence can still occur despite Lebesgue function divergence.
overview.problemStatement: Given points a_i^n ∈ [-1,1], define Lagrange basis polynomials p_i^n and interpolation L^n f(x) = Σ f(a_i^n) p_i^n(x). The Lebesgue function is λ_n(x) = Σ |p_i^n(x)|. Q1: Can λ_n(x) → ∞ yet L^n f(x) → f(x) for some x? Q2: Can λ_n(x) → ∞ for ALL x, yet still have convergence somewhere?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize interpolation points, Lagrange basis polynomials, the interpolation operator, the Lebesgue function and constant, Bernstein's theorem, Erdős-Vértesi theorem, the two main questions, special point sequences (Chebyshev, equidistant), convergence conditions, and measure-theoretic aspects.
keyInsights: Bernstein (1931): limsup λ_n(x₀) = ∞ for some x₀
Erdős-Vértesi (1980): |L^n f(x)| → ∞ a.e. for some continuous f
Chebyshev nodes minimize Lebesgue constant: Λ_n ~ (2/π) log n
Equidistant nodes have exponential Lebesgue constant growth
Faber's theorem: No universal uniform convergence

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #671 on Lagrange interpolation convergence. Despite Bernstein's divergence theorem and Erdős-Vértesi's a.e. divergence result, the questions ask whether pointwise convergence can still occur when the Lebesgue function diverges.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would clarify the subtle relationship between the Lebesgue function (which controls error) and actual convergence behavior. The problem connects approximation theory with measure theory.
openQuestions: Can L^n f(x) → f(x) at points where λ_n(x) → ∞? (Q1, $250)
Can λ_n(x) → ∞ everywhere yet still have some convergence? (Q2)
What is the measure of convergence/divergence sets?
Are there special point sequences that answer the questions?
